div.head: LXXXVII.

OF THE SAME ON OUR LORD'S SAYING, " I WILL NOT DRINK WITH YOU HENCEFORTH OF THIS PRODUCT OF THE VINE TILL THE DAY ON WHICH I SHALL DRINK IT ANEW WITH YOU IN MY FATHER'S KINGDOM"Matth. XXVI, 20., FROM THE 60th LETTER The ref. to the book and series seems to have fallen out., WHICH WAS ADDRESSED TO LEONTIUS THE PRESBYTERProbably the Leont. of Select Letters of Severus, I, 5. The extract down to 'says' (p. 319, 1. 10) is published in Greek in Cramer, Cat. in Luc. et Jo., p. 155, where it begins: πρὸς ταῦτα ἀποκρίνεται Σ. ὁ ἐπισκ. Αντ. πρὸς Λ. πρεσβ. γράφων οὕτω. Τοῦτο διπλῆν τὴν ἀπόδοσιν ἔχει κ. τὴν ἐξήγησιν. Ὡ μὲν γ. ἁγιώτατος τῆς ΚΠ. ἐπισκ. Ι. #check transcription# From 'the new' (p. 319, 1. 1)' to the same point it is also in Mai. Class. Auct., x, 437 in a shorter and transposed form..
div.p:
But the words spoken by our Saviour to the disciples at the institution of the new and divine mystery, "I will not drink henceforth of this product of the vine till the day on which I shall drink it with you new in my Father's kingdom" are explained and interpreted in two ways. John bishop of
Constantinople says that the new drinking of the cup is that occasion on which he drank with his disciples after the Resurrection Gr. adds ἐκ νεκρῶν., thereby confirming the natureGr. ναόν. of the body which rose, and eradicating the profane notion of phantasyGr. φιλοδοξίας.; for the holy Peter is related in the Actsπρᾶξις. of the Apostles to have said to Cornelius, "Us who ate and drank with him after he rose from the dead"Acts x, 41; Jo. Chrys., In Matth. Horn. LXXXII, 2. (ed. Par. 2a, VII, 884).. But Gregory the Theologian in the homily on the Passover says that the new drinking of the cup is the revelation of the divine conceptions that shall take place and is expected in the kingdom of the heavensGr. τὴν ἐν τῇ μελλούσῃ κ. προσδοκωμένῃ βασιλείᾳ τῶν οὐρανῶν τῶν θείων νοημάτων ἑπηγγελμένων (l. ἐπηγγελμένων) ἡμῖν ἀποκάλυψιν., when mirrors and riddles are done away, and the sight face to face is revealed, as the divine apostle says1 Cor. XIII, 12.. But it is fitting that I should quote to you these words of the doctor, the contents of which are as follows: "We shall receive the Passover, but now symbolicallyBy omitting ἔτι the translator has lost the point of the sentence., and a Passover that is more plainly revealed than the old one (for I am bold enough to say that the legal Passover was an obscurer symbol of a symbol); but a little later
one thatis more perfect and purer, when the Word shall drink it new with us in the Father's kingdom, revealing to us and teaching us things that he has now shown ohscurely; for that which is now made to appear is always new. But, what the drinking and enjoyment is, it is ours to learn, but his to teach, and to show the matter to his disciples. For even the teaching is the food of him who teaches"Or. XLV, 23. The last sentence runs: Τροφὴ γοῦν ἐστὶν ἡ δίδαξις κ. τοῦ τρέφοντος.. And very well did the Theologian give expression to these words; for our Lord also reckons our profit his own food and drink; for thus also he says in the gospel, "My food is to do my Father's will"John iv, 34.; and again, when he was about to speak to the men from Samaria, he said to the disciples, "I have food to eat, which ye know not"Ibid., 32..
